narrativeStructure.banishment: Susanoo exiled from heaven after rampage that drove Amaterasu into hiding
narrativeStructure.dragonDescription: Eight heads, eight tails, eyes red like winter cherries, belly always bloody
narrativeStructure.plan: Susanoo demands marriage to girl, transforms her into comb for safety
narrativeStructure.crisis: Yamata-no-Orochi (8-headed dragon) has devoured 7 daughters, will take 8th
narrativeStructure.resolution: Marries Kushinadahime, builds palace in Izumo, gives sword to Amaterasu
narrativeStructure.encounter: Meets elderly couple and daughter Kushinadahime weeping
narrativeStructure.discovery: Finds Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi sword in fourth tail
narrativeStructure.battle: Dragon drinks all eight vats, becomes drunk, Susanoo slays all eight heads
narrativeStructure.trap: Prepares eight vats of strong sake to intoxicate dragon

name: Headed Serpent
participants: Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi - Parents of Kushinadahime

historicalContext.context: Susanoo's redemption after banishment from heaven
historicalContext.discovery: Origin myth for Kusanagi sword (Imperial Regalia)
historicalContext.sources: Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE)

significance.sacrifice: Seven daughters sacrificed before hero arrives - common folklore motif
significance.imperialRegalia: Kusanagi becomes one of Three Sacred Treasures validating imperial rule
significance.redemption: Violent, chaotic Susanoo transforms into heroic protector
significance.marriage: Monster-slaying wins bride - archetypal reward structure
significance.heroPattern: Classic dragon-slayer narrative - cunning plus courage defeats monster

description: The myth of Susanoo slaying Yamata-no-Orochi is one of the most celebrated hero tales in Japanese mythology, recorded in the Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE). After being banished from heaven for his violent behavior, the storm god Susanoo descends to earth where he encounters a family terrorized by an eight-headed, eight-tailed dragon. Through cunning and courage, Susanoo slays the monster, rescues a maiden, and discovers within the dragon's tail the legendary sword Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi - one of the Three Sacred Treasures of Japan.

theologicalAnalysis.dragonSlayer: The defeat of the serpent/dragon is a universal mythic pattern that finds its fullest expression in Christ's victory over 'that ancient serpent, who is the devil' (Revelation 20:2)
theologicalAnalysis.redemptionThroughHeroism: Susanoo's redemption from exile through heroic action parallels biblical themes of restoration through faithfulness and courage
theologicalAnalysis.protectorOfInnocent: The rescue of Kushinadahime from the dragon represents the archetypal protection of the vulnerable, fulfilled in Christ as Good Shepherd
theologicalAnalysis.cunningAndCourage: The combination of strategic wisdom (sake trap) and martial courage reflects the biblical integration of prudence and fortitude

christian.serpentSlaying: The eight-headed serpent recalls the biblical serpent (Genesis 3), the Leviathan (Job 41), and 'the dragon, that ancient serpent' (Revelation 12:9)
christian.christVsDragon: Revelation 12 depicts cosmic conflict between Christ/Michael and the dragon - Susanoo's victory is a pagan prefigurement of this ultimate victory
christian.saintGeorge: The patron saint of England slaying the dragon to rescue a maiden is a Christian appropriation of this universal dragon-slayer archetype
christian.redemptionOfExile: Susanoo's redemption from exile through heroic service anticipates the biblical pattern of restoration - 'if anyone cleanses himself... he will be a vessel for honorable use' (2 Timothy 2:21)
christian.brideRescue: The rescue and marriage to Kushinadahime parallels the biblical image of Christ rescuing His bride, the Church (Ephesians 5:25-27)

comparativeNotes.naturalTheology: The universal dragon-slayer myth reflects humanity's intuition that evil is a monstrous force requiring a heroic deliverer - pointing toward the Gospel's proclamation of Christ's victory

patristicCommentary.irenaeus: Irenaeus saw Christ's victory over Satan as the true dragon-slaying that pagan myths dimly anticipated, 'binding the strong man' (Mark 3:27)
patristicCommentary.origen: Origen's commentary on the serpent in Genesis provides vocabulary for understanding how pagan serpent myths relate to the biblical narrative of spiritual warfare
patristicCommentary.augustine: Augustine interpreted the dragon/serpent as symbol of the devil throughout Scripture, applicable to understanding Japanese mythology
patristicCommentary.gregoryTheGreat: Gregory's moral interpretation of Leviathan/Behemoth in Job informs how the Church reads dragon myths as anticipations of spiritual reality

biblicalParallels: Revelation 12:9 - The great dragon was thrown down, that ancient serpent, who is called the devil
Revelation 20:2 - He seized the dragon, that ancient serpent, who is the devil and Satan
Genesis 3:15 - He shall bruise your head, and you shall bruise his heel (protoevangelium)
Job 41 - Description of Leviathan, the great sea monster
Psalm 74:13-14 - You broke the heads of Leviathan; you crushed the heads of the sea monsters
Isaiah 27:1 - The Lord will punish Leviathan the fleeing serpent
Ephesians 5:25-27 - Christ loved the Church and gave Himself up for her (bride rescue)
Mark 3:27 - No one can enter a strong man's house and plunder his goods unless he first binds the strong man
typologicalReading: Susanoo's slaying of Yamata-no-Orochi represents one of humanity's clearest natural prefigurements of Christ's victory over evil. The eight-headed serpent, devouring innocent maidens, embodies the destructive power that Scripture identifies with Satan - 'the thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy' (John 10:10). Susanoo's use of both cunning and courage, his rescue of the bride, and his discovery of the sacred sword all point toward the fullness of Christ's redemptive work. The Church's veneration of dragon-slaying saints (George, Michael, Margaret) demonstrates how this mythic pattern was consciously appropriated as preparation for the Gospel. Where Susanoo's victory is local and temporary, Christ's triumph is cosmic and eternal: 'He disarmed the rulers and authorities and put them to open shame, by triumphing over them' (Colossians 2:15).

academic: Basil Hall Chamberlain, 'Ko-ji-ki: Records of Ancient Matters' (1882)
Joseph Campbell, 'The Hero with a Thousand Faces' (1949)
theological: Gustav Aulen, 'Christus Victor' (1931) - classic work on Christ's victory over evil powers
Henri de Lubac, 'Medieval Exegesis' (on typological reading)
patristic: Augustine, 'City of God' XX (on the dragon in Revelation)

definition: The hero myth of Susanoo slaying the eight-headed dragon Yamata-no-Orochi, rescuing a maiden, and discovering the sacred sword Kusanagi, representing redemption through heroic action and the discovery of imperial legitimacy.
examples: The dragon's consumption of seven daughters
Susanoo's clever trap using sake to intoxicate the dragon
Discovery of Kusanagi sword in the dragon's fourth tail
practitioners: Samurai and martial artists honoring the warrior code
Shinto priests maintaining sacred sword veneration
Those engaging redemption and transformation stories
applications: Martial virtue and protection of the vulnerable
